metadata.title: DON’T SETTLE FOR AVERAGE, GO FOR THE MAX: FUZZY SETS AND MAX-POOLED WORD VECTORS
metadata.author: Vitalii Zhelezniak, Aleksandar Savkov, April Shen, Francesco Moramarco, Jack Flann & Nils Y. Hammerla Babylon Health {vitali.zhelezniak, sasho.savkov, firstname.lastname} @babylonhealth.com
metadata.abstract: Recent literature suggests that averaged word vectors followed by simple postprocessing outperform many deep learning methods on semantic textual similarity tasks. Furthermore, when averaged word vectors are trained supervised on large corpora of paraphrases, they achieve state-of-the-art results on standard STS benchmarks. Inspired by these insights, we push the limits of word embeddings even further. We propose a novel fuzzy bag-of-words (FBoW) representation for text that contains all the words in the vocabulary simultaneously but with different degrees of membership, which are derived from similarities between word vectors. We show that max-pooled word vectors are only a special case of fuzzy BoW and should be compared via fuzzy Jaccard index rather than cosine similarity. Finally, we propose DynaMax, a completely unsupervised and non-parametric similarity measure that dynamically extracts and max-pools good features depending on the sentence pair. This method is both efficient and easy to implement, yet outperforms current baselines on STS tasks by a large margin and is even competitive with supervised word vectors trained to directly optimise cosine similarity.

highlights: Natural languages are able to encode sentences with similar meanings using very different vocabulary and grammatical constructs, which makes determining the semantic similarity between pieces of text a challenge

When word vectors are trained unsupervised, this simple representation combined with the fuzzy Jaccard index is already a stronger baseline for semantic textual similarity than the averaged word vector with cosine similarity, as we will see in Section 4

From the linear-algebraic point of view, fuzzy BoW is really the same as projecting word embeddings on a subspace of Rd spanned by the rows of U , followed by max-pooling of the features extracted by this projection
We show that max-pooled word vectors are a special case of fuzzy bag-of-words, which implies that they should be compared via the fuzzy Jaccard index rather than the more standard cosine similarity
We present a simple and novel algorithm, DynaMax, which corresponds to projecting word vectors onto a subspace dynamically generated by the given sentences before max-pooling over the features
DynaMax outperforms averaged word vectors compared with cosine similarity on every benchmark Semantic Textual Similarity task when word vectors are trained unsupervised
key_statements: Natural languages are able to encode sentences with similar meanings using very different vocabulary and grammatical constructs, which makes determining the semantic similarity between pieces of text a challenge

BoW was largely eclipsed by representations learned through neural networks, ranging from shallow (Le & Mikolov, 2014; Hill et al, 2016) to recurrent (Kiros et al, 2015; Conneau et al, 2017; Subramanian et al, 2018a), recursive (Socher et al, 2013; Tai et al, 2015), convolutional (Kalchbrenner et al, 2014; Kim, 2014), self-attentive (Vaswani et al, 2017; Cer et al, 2018a) and hybrid architectures (Gan et al, 2017; Tang et al, 2017; Zhelezniak et al, 2018)
We propose a novel fuzzy bag-of-words (FBoW) representation for text
Unlike classical BoW, fuzzy BoW contains all the words in the vocabulary simultaneously but with different degrees of membership, which are derived from similarities between word vectors
We show that max-pooled word vectors are a special case of fuzzy BoW
Since max-pooled vectors are just a special case of fuzzy BoW, we show that the fuzzy Jaccard index is a more suitable alternative to cosine similarity for comparing these representations
We propose DynaMax, a completely unsupervised and non-parametric similarity measure that dynamically extracts and max-pools good features depending on the sentence pair
We found that recent literature on Semantic Textual Similarity tends to apply unspecified or inappropriate parametric tests, or leave out significance analysis altogether in the majority of cases
We considered the universe and the word embedding matrix to be the same, i.e. U = W

When word vectors are trained unsupervised, this simple representation combined with the fuzzy Jaccard index is already a stronger baseline for semantic textual similarity than the averaged word vector with cosine similarity, as we will see in Section 4

From the linear-algebraic point of view, fuzzy BoW is really the same as projecting word embeddings on a subspace of Rd spanned by the rows of U , followed by max-pooling of the features extracted by this projection
DynaMax shows the best performance across all tasks, possibly thanks to its superior ability to extract and max-pool good features from word vectors
To strengthen our empirical findings, we provide ablation studies for DynaMax in Appendix C, showing that the different components of the algorithm each contribute to its strong performance
We show that max-pooled word vectors are a special case of fuzzy bag-of-words, which implies that they should be compared via the fuzzy Jaccard index rather than the more standard cosine similarity
We present a simple and novel algorithm, DynaMax, which corresponds to projecting word vectors onto a subspace dynamically generated by the given sentences before max-pooling over the features
DynaMax outperforms averaged word vectors compared with cosine similarity on every benchmark Semantic Textual Similarity task when word vectors are trained unsupervised
summary: Natural languages are able to encode sentences with similar meanings using very different vocabulary and grammatical constructs, which makes determining the semantic similarity between pieces of text a challenge.
Since max-pooled vectors are just a special case of fuzzy BoW, we show that the fuzzy Jaccard index is a more suitable alternative to cosine similarity for comparing these representations.
DynaMax outperforms averaged word vector with cosine similarity on every benchmark STS task when word vectors are trained unsupervised.
It’s very tempting to just sum or average over all μ(i), i.e. But we remember: in fuzzy set theory the union of the membership vectors is realised by the element-wise max-pooling.
From this we see that max-pooled word vectors are only a special case of fuzzy BoW.

When word vectors are trained unsupervised, this simple representation combined with the fuzzy Jaccard index is already a stronger baseline for semantic textual similarity than the averaged word vector with cosine similarity, as we will see in Section 4.
The fuzzy Jaccard index works for max-pooled word vectors but completely fails for averaged word vectors.

From the linear-algebraic point of view, fuzzy BoW is really the same as projecting word embeddings on a subspace of Rd spanned by the rows of U , followed by max-pooling of the features extracted by this projection.
This supports our derivation of max-pooled vectors as a special case of fuzzy BoW, which should be compared via fuzzy set similarity measures and not cosine similarity.
DynaMax shows the best performance across all tasks, possibly thanks to its superior ability to extract and max-pool good features from word vectors.
In this work we combine word embeddings with classic BoW representations using fuzzy set theory.
We show that max-pooled word vectors are a special case of FBoW, which implies that they should be compared via the fuzzy Jaccard index rather than the more standard cosine similarity.
We present a simple and novel algorithm, DynaMax, which corresponds to projecting word vectors onto a subspace dynamically generated by the given sentences before max-pooling over the features.
DynaMax outperforms averaged word vectors compared with cosine similarity on every benchmark STS task when word vectors are trained unsupervised.
These methods are not limited to NLP and word embeddings, but can be used in any setting where one needs to compute similarity between sets of elements that have rich vector representations.
It even performs comparably to supervised vectors that directly optimise cosine similarity between paraphrases, despite being completely unrelated to that objective
headline: We propose a novel fuzzy bag-of-words representation for text that contains all the words in the vocabulary simultaneously but with different degrees of membership, which are derived from similarities between word vectors
